what: Not required for {ospsuite} version equal or above 12.1.0
title: PK-Sim Installation
text: Since ospsuite released version 12.1.0, necessary OSPSuite PK-Sim dependencies included package. Therefore, need install extra software use ospsuite. Also, ospsuite fully self contained independant version OSPSuite PK-Sim installed user computer. However, script provided package developpers order get/update latest dependencies (core files):

title: PK-Sim Installation
text: features available ospsuite require installation PK-Sim. necessary PK-Sim installation matches version ospsuite (.e use ospsuite v11.y.z, need PK-Sim v11 installed). possible install PK-Sim globally whole system, also locally per-project basis. following sections describe options.

title: PK-Sim Installation
text: Download PK-Sim Download pk-sim-portable-setup.zip matching version ospsuite using . Enable using .dll zip Windows Defender prevents applications downloaded untrusted sources loaded. extracting downloaded portable version, unblock . Right click downloaded archive select “Properties” (Windows 11, select “Show options” first), Properties-window, select checkbox “Unblock”. Close R sessions Make sure R session ospsuite loaded close R session. Extract PK-Sim Extract downloaded portable PK-Sim location C:/Open Systems Pharmacology/ (folder exist, create ). Change version number folder name match PK-Sim version downloaded keeping two digits. example, downloaded PK-Sim 11.3.208, folder name PK-Sim 11.0.

what: Install and use PK-Sim in a project
title: PK-Sim Installation
text: Follow steps previous section download extract PK-Sim PKSim folder project folder. , include following code lines beginning projects scripts: ⚠️ Important: run command without path wrong path , must restart R session running correct path. (related issue)

title: Creating individuals
text: physiology individual defined values simulation parameters. simulate specific individual, one generate set parameter values apply values model. NOTE: Currently, individuals species original *.pkml simulation can applied. .e., simulation exported PK-Sim represents human individual, possible simulate another human individual different population, gender, etc., possible simulate rat. Though technically possible, simulation produce results, valid. first step creating object describing individual characteristics. see list available values arguments species, population (human), gender (human), use enums Species, HumanPopulation, Gender, respectively. object passed function createIndividual generate set parameter values. algorithm behind used PK-Sim creating Individual-Building Block. output contains two lists parameters: distributedParameters: parameters differ individuals selected species derivedParameters: parameters defined formulas simulation applying generated individual parameter set simulation R, parameters distributedParameters overwritten, otherwise formula dependencies may destroyed. Generated parameter values can conveniently applied using setParameterValuesByPath method:
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rSharp  # If no unit is specified, the default units are used. For "weight" it is "kg", for "age" it is "year(s)". individualCharacteristics <- createIndividualCharacteristics(   species    = Species$Human,   population = HumanPopulation$Japanese_Population,   gender     = Gender$Female,   weight     = 75,   height     = 1.75,   heightUnit = "m",   age        = 43 ) print(individualCharacteristics) #> <IndividualCharacteristics> #>   • Species: Human #>   • Population: Japanese_Population #>   • Gender: FEMALE #>   • Age: 43.00 [year(s)] #>   • Gestational age: 40.00 [week(s)] #>   • Weight: 75.00 [kg] #>   • Height: 1.75 [m]  individual <- createIndividual(individualCharacteristics = individualCharacteristics)  # we will not be printing this given the long length of the output, but you can # see the details by running: # print(individual) library(ospsuite)  # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") print(simFilePath) #> [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/ospsuite/extdata/Aciclovir.pkml" sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Apply individual parameters setParameterValuesByPath(   parameterPaths = individual$distributedParameters$paths,   values         = individual$distributedParameters$values,   simulation     = sim )

title: Creating individuals
text: PK-Sim database includes ontogeny information proteins (see (PK-Sim Ontogeny Database)[https://github.com/Open-Systems-Pharmacology/OSPSuite.Documentation/blob/master/PK-Sim%20Ontogeny%20Database%20Version%207.3.pdf]). protein molecule present simulation, possible add ontogeny information one predefined proteins. example, possible set ontogeny protein MyProtein value ontogeny CYP3A4 enzyme specified individual. list supported ontogenies stored StandardOntogeny-list.
code: library(ospsuite)  # All supported ontogenies print(StandardOntogeny) #> $CYP1A2 #> [1] "CYP1A2" #>  #> $CYP2C18 #> [1] "CYP2C18" #>  #> $CYP2C19 #> [1] "CYP2C19" #>  #> $CYP2C8 #> [1] "CYP2C8" #>  #> $CYP2C9 #> [1] "CYP2C9" #>  #> $CYP2D6 #> [1] "CYP2D6" #>  #> $CYP2E1 #> [1] "CYP2E1" #>  #> $CYP3A4 #> [1] "CYP3A4" #>  #> $CYP3A5 #> [1] "CYP3A5" #>  #> $CYP3A7 #> [1] "CYP3A7" #>  #> $UGT1A1 #> [1] "UGT1A1" #>  #> $UGT1A4 #> [1] "UGT1A4" #>  #> $UGT1A6 #> [1] "UGT1A6" #>  #> $UGT1A9 #> [1] "UGT1A9" #>  #> $UGT2B4 #> [1] "UGT2B4" #>  #> $UGT2B7 #> [1] "UGT2B7"  # Create the ontogeny for the protein "MyProtein" based on ontology of CYP3A4 myProteinOntogeny <- MoleculeOntogeny$new(molecule = "MyProtein", ontogeny = StandardOntogeny$CYP3A4) print(myProteinOntogeny) #> <MoleculeOntogeny> #>   • Molecule: MyProtein #>   • Ontogeny: CYP3A4  # Add this ontogeny to the individual characteristics used to create the individual parameters set individualCharacterstics <- createIndividualCharacteristics(   species            = Species$Human,   population         = HumanPopulation$Japanese_Population,   gender             = Gender$Female,   weight             = 75,   height             = 1.75,   heightUnit         = "m",   age                = 43,   moleculeOntogenies = myProteinOntogeny ) print(individualCharacterstics) #> <IndividualCharacteristics> #>   • Species: Human #>   • Population: Japanese_Population #>   • Gender: FEMALE #>   • Age: 43.00 [year(s)] #>   • Gestational age: 40.00 [week(s)] #>   • Weight: 75.00 [kg] #>   • Height: 1.75 [m] #>  #> ── Molecule Ontogenies ── #>  #> [1] "Molecule 'MyProtein' with ontogeny 'CYP3A4'"  individual <- createIndividual(individualCharacteristics = individualCharacterstics)

title: Population simulations
text: Population simulations can easily performed R combining simulation loaded *.pkml file population information created PK-Sim exported CSV format (details, please refer OSPS online documentation) created directly R (see Creating populations).

title: Population simulations
text: method loadPopulation creates object Population class can passed runSimulations() method (see Running simulations retrieving results).
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rSharp # Load population information from csv popFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "pop.csv", package = "ospsuite") myPopulation <- loadPopulation(csvPopulationFile = popFilePath) print(myPopulation) #> <Population> #>   • Number of Individuals: 10

title: Population simulations
text: Similar creating individual parameter sets (see Creating individuals), population created population characteristics created calling method createPopulationCharacteristics(). see list available values arguments species population (human), use enums Species HumanPopulation, respectively. returned object type PopulationCharacteristics passed function createPopulation generate set parameter values. algorithm behind used PK-Sim creating population. Molecule ontogenies can added described vignette Creating individuals.
code: library(ospsuite)  # If no unit is specified, the default units are used. For "height" it is "dm", for "weight" it is "kg", for "age" it is "year(s)". populationCharacteristics <- createPopulationCharacteristics(   species             = Species$Human,   population          = HumanPopulation$Asian_Tanaka_1996,   numberOfIndividuals = 50,   proportionOfFemales = 50,   weightMin           = 30,   weightMax           = 98,   weightUnit          = "kg",   heightMin           = NULL,   heightMax           = NULL,   ageMin              = 0,   ageMax              = 80,   ageUnit             = "year(s)" ) print(populationCharacteristics) #> <PopulationCharacteristics> #>   • Species: Human #>   • Population: Asian_Tanaka_1996 #>   • Number of individuals: 50 #>   • Proportion of females: 50 #>   • Age: [0.00 year(s)..80.00 year(s)] #>   • Gestational age: ]-Inf..+Inf[ #>   • Weight: [30.00 kg..98.00 kg] #>   • Height: ]-Inf..+Inf[ #>   • BMI: ]-Inf..+Inf[  # Create population from population characteristics result <- createPopulation(populationCharacteristics = populationCharacteristics) myPopulation <- result$population print(myPopulation) #> <Population> #>   • Number of Individuals: 50

title: Population simulations
text: run population simulation, Population object created createPopulation method must passed runSimulation() method: Population simulations run parallel multi-core machines - one core simulates subset individuals defined population. default, number cores used equals maximal number logical cores available minus one. user can change default behavior providing custom SimulationRunOptions(). Simulated time-value pairs specific output SimulationResults-object returned runSimulation method can accessed method getOutputValues. user can provide either path(s) output (can molecule, parameter, observer), object(s) type Molecule, Parameter, Quantity (observers) argument quantitiesOrPaths. output specified, outputs available simulation results returned. paths available outputs can accessed via getOutputValues() returns list two entries: data metadata: IndividualId Time vector simulated time values (minutes, equal outputs) vector simulated entries output requested. values IndividualId, Time, simulated outputs, appended simulated individual. Note results non-monotonously increasing column Time.  get results specific individual set individuals, argument individualIds method getOutputValues() can specified:  information running simulations, please refer Running simulations retrieving results.
code: library(ospsuite)  # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Run population simulation simulationResults <- runSimulations(simulations = sim, population = myPopulation)[[1]] print(simulationResults) #> <SimulationResults> #>   • Number of individuals: 50 #> For paths: #>   • Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood) # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Create a SimulationRunOptions object simRunOptions <- SimulationRunOptions$new() print(simRunOptions) #> <SimulationRunOptions> #>   • numberOfCores: 3 #>   • checkForNegativeValues: TRUE #>   • showProgress: FALSE  # Change the maximal number of cores to use and show a progress bar during simulation simRunOptions$numberOfCores <- 3 simRunOptions$showProgress <- TRUE  # Run population simulation with custom options populationResults <- runSimulations(simulations = sim, population = myPopulation, simulationRunOptions = simRunOptions)[[1]] print(populationResults) #> <SimulationResults> #>   • Number of individuals: 50 #> For paths: #>   • Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood) populationResults$allQuantityPaths #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)" # Get simulated results by path resultsPath <- populationResults$allQuantityPaths[[1]] print(resultsPath) #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)"  resultsData <- getOutputValues(populationResults, quantitiesOrPaths = resultsPath)  resultsTime <- resultsData$data$Time resultsValues <- resultsData$data$`Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)`  plot(resultsTime, resultsValues, type = "l") # Get simulated results by path resultsPath <- populationResults$allQuantityPaths[[1]] print(resultsPath) #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)"  # Get only the results for individuals with IDs 1 and 2 resultsData <- getOutputValues(populationResults, quantitiesOrPaths = resultsPath, individualIds = c(1, 2))  resultsTime <- resultsData$data$Time resultsValues <- resultsData$data$`Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)`  plot(resultsTime, resultsValues, type = "l")

title: Visualizations with `DataCombined`
text: already seen DataCombined class can utilized store observed /simulated data (, read Working DataCombined class). Let’s first create DataCombined object, use demonstrate different visualizations available.
code: library(ospsuite)  # simulated data simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath) simResults <- runSimulations(sim)[[1]] outputPath <- "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)"  # observed data obsData <- lapply(   c("ObsDataAciclovir_1.pkml", "ObsDataAciclovir_2.pkml", "ObsDataAciclovir_3.pkml"),   function(x) loadDataSetFromPKML(system.file("extdata", x, package = "ospsuite")) ) names(obsData) <- lapply(obsData, function(x) x$name)  myDataCombined <- DataCombined$new()  myDataCombined$addSimulationResults(   simulationResults = simResults,   quantitiesOrPaths = outputPath,   groups = "Aciclovir PVB" )  myDataCombined$addDataSets(   obsData$`Vergin 1995.Iv`,   groups = "Aciclovir PVB" )

title: Visualizations with `DataCombined`
text: Time profile plots visualize measured simulated values time help assess observed data (represented symbols error bars) match simulated data (represented lines).

title: Visualizations with `DataCombined`
text: Observed versus simulated plots allow assess far simulated results observed values.  identity line represents perfect correspondence simulated values observed ones. default, “two-fold” range marked dashed lines. “x-fold” range defined values x-fold higher 1/x-fold lower observed ones. user can specify multiple ranges foldDistance argument.

what: Residuals versus time or vs simulated scatter plot
title: Visualizations with `DataCombined`
text: Residual plots show systematic bias simulated values either high-concentration low-concentration regions, , alternatively, early late time periods.   Residuals log values can visualized scaling argument.

title: Visualizations with `DataCombined`
text: look feel plots can customized using DefaultPlotConfiguration class, provides various class members can used modify appearance plot. configuration class can passed plotting functions:
code: myPlotConfiguration <- DefaultPlotConfiguration$new()  # Define x units myPlotConfiguration$xUnit <- ospUnits$Time$s # Define y units myPlotConfiguration$yUnit <- ospUnits$`Concentration [mass]`$`µg/l` # Change y axis scaling to logarithmic myPlotConfiguration$yAxisScale <- tlf::Scaling$log  myPlotConfiguration$title <- "Example: Customizing a Plot" myPlotConfiguration$subtitle <- "Using DefaultPlotConfiguration class" myPlotConfiguration$caption <- "Source: Aciclovir data"  myPlotConfiguration$legendPosition <- tlf::LegendPositions$outsideRight plotIndividualTimeProfile(myDataCombined, myPlotConfiguration)

title: Visualizations with `DataCombined`
text: plotXXX() returns ggplot2 object. Lets create different plots DataCombined store variables. plots can combined multi-panel figure using PlotGridConfiguration used plotGrid() function create figure.  function try arrange panels number rows equals number colums. can also specify number rows columns PlotGridConfiguration:  Check documentation PlotGridConfiguration class list supported properties.
code: indivProfile <- plotIndividualTimeProfile(myDataCombined, myPlotConfiguration) obsVsSim <- plotObservedVsSimulated(myDataCombined, myPlotConfiguration) resVsSim <- plotResidualsVsSimulated(myDataCombined) resVsTime <- plotResidualsVsTime(myDataCombined) plotGridConfiguration <- PlotGridConfiguration$new() plotGridConfiguration$tagLevels <- "a" plotGridConfiguration$title <- "Multiple plots in one figure"  plotGridConfiguration$addPlots(plots = list(indivProfile, obsVsSim, resVsSim, resVsTime))  plotGrid(plotGridConfiguration) plotGridConfiguration$nColumns <- 1  plotGrid(plotGridConfiguration)

title: Visualizations with `DataCombined`
text: plotting functions return ggplot objects can modified. save plot file, use ExportConfiguration object. can edit various properties export, including resolution, file format, file name.
code: # Create new export configuration exportConfiguration <- tlf::ExportConfiguration$new() # Define the path to the folder where the file will be stored exportConfiguration$path <- "../OutputFigures" # Define the name of the file exportConfiguration$name <- "MultiPanelPlot" # Resolution exportConfiguration$dpi <- 600  # Store the plot into a variable and export it to a file plotObject <- plotIndividualTimeProfile(myDataCombined)  exportConfiguration$savePlot(plotObject)

title: Visualizations with `DataCombined`
text: plotting functions ospsuite make use tlf library prepare visualizations. know library, see website.

title: Working with `DataCombined` class
text: Modeling Simulation (M&S) workflows, often need work multiple observed /simulated datasets. datasets can linked together group (e.g., simulated corresponding observed data) analysis visualization. DataCombined class ospsuite provides container store data, group , transform (e.g. scale offset). class accepts data coming SimulationResults DataSet object (see Observed data). Let’s first generate simulation results load observed data. Typically, DataCombined used create figures using plotXXX() functions. different plot types described Visualizations DataCombined. visualize different functionalities DataCombined document, use plotIndividualTimeProfile() function.
code: library(ospsuite)  # Simulation results simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath) simResults <- runSimulations(sim)[[1]] outputPath <- "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)"  # observed data obsData <- lapply(   c("ObsDataAciclovir_1.pkml", "ObsDataAciclovir_2.pkml", "ObsDataAciclovir_3.pkml"),   function(x) loadDataSetFromPKML(system.file("extdata", x, package = "ospsuite")) ) # Name the elements of the list according to the names of the loaded `DataSet`. names(obsData) <- lapply(obsData, function(x) x$name)

title: Working with `DataCombined` class
text: First, create new instance DataCombined class. add simulated results object using $addSimulationResults(): Next add observed data object using $addDataSets(): Every data, simulated results DataSet, must unique name within DataCombined. specified user, path simulated results $name property DataSet used name. Alternatively, can define name adding data, example adding simulated results. things keep mind : doesn’t matter order observed simulated datasets added. can add multiple DataSet objects $addDataSets() method call. can add single instance SimulationResults $addSimulationResults() method call. add dataset name existing (e.g., adding simulation results multiple simulations specifying name, path results used name), new data replace existing.
code: myDataCombined <- DataCombined$new() myDataCombined$addSimulationResults(   simulationResults = simResults,   quantitiesOrPaths = outputPath,   names = "Aciclovir Plasma",   groups = "Aciclovir PVB" ) myDataCombined$addDataSets(   obsData$`Vergin 1995.Iv`,   groups = "Aciclovir PVB" )

title: Working with `DataCombined` class
text: Since DataCombined object can store many datasets, may naturally form grouping wish track object. $addDataSets() $addSimulationResults() allow group specification via groups argument. plotted, data sets without grouping appear distinct color, line style (simulated results), symbol style (observed data) separate entry legend, name data set legend entry. Though possible group data different dimensions, makes sense group data sets dimension (dimensions can transformed , like Amount Mass) order able compare data. Grouping data sets different dimensions likely result error trying create plots calculating residuals DataCombined. Let’s create DataCombined add simulation results observed data without specifying grouping create time profile:  specify groups add datasets, wish update groupings later, can use $setGroups() method. data within one group get one entry legend name group, plotted color.  point, can check current names groupings following active field:
code: myDataCombined <- DataCombined$new()  myDataCombined$addSimulationResults(   simulationResults = simResults,   quantitiesOrPaths = outputPath,   names = "Aciclovir Plasma" )  myDataCombined$addDataSets(   obsData$`Vergin 1995.Iv` )  plotIndividualTimeProfile(dataCombined = myDataCombined) myDataCombined$setGroups(   names = c("Aciclovir Plasma", obsData$`Vergin 1995.Iv`$name),   groups = c("Aciclovir PVB", "Aciclovir PVB") )  plotIndividualTimeProfile(dataCombined = myDataCombined) myDataCombined$groupMap #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   name             group         dataType  #>   <chr>            <chr>         <chr>     #> 1 Aciclovir Plasma Aciclovir PVB simulated #> 2 Vergin 1995.Iv   Aciclovir PVB observed

title: Working with `DataCombined` class
text: Sometimes raw data included DataCombined needs transformed using specified offset scale factor values. supported via $setDataTransformations() method, can specify names datasets, offsets scale factors. arguments scalar (.e., length 1), value applied specified names. Scale factors unitless values raw data values multiplied, offsets added raw values without conversion must therefore units raw data. internal data frame DataCombined transformed specified parameters, new columns computed : x values: newXValue = (rawXValue + xOffset) * xScaleFactor y values: newYValue = (rawYValue + yOffset) * yScaleFactor arithmetic error: newErrorValue = rawErrorValue * abs(yScaleFactor) geometric error: transformation. point, can check applied offsets scale factors following active field: Now lets take closer look possible situations apply transformations. Consider observed data examples . reports concentrations aciclovir single intravenous administration.  However, might want use data set simulation aciclovir administered 24 hours simulation begin. able compare simulation results data set, can offset observed data time 24 hours. Keep mind offset must given unit data set values .  next step, want normalize observed concentrations dose. can easily achieve scale factor. next example, normalize observed values 250 mg dose setting yScaleFactor 1/250: Finally, offsetting observation values might useful working measurements endogenous substrates, hormone glucagon, want correct individual specific baseline levels hormone.
code: myDataCombined$dataTransformations #> # A tibble: 2 × 5 #>   name             xOffsets yOffsets xScaleFactors yScaleFactors #>   <chr>               <dbl>    <dbl>         <dbl>         <dbl> #> 1 Aciclovir Plasma        0        0             1             1 #> 2 Vergin 1995.Iv          0        0             1             1 myDataCombinedTranformations <- DataCombined$new()  myDataCombinedTranformations$addDataSets(   obsData$`Vergin 1995.Iv` )  plotIndividualTimeProfile(dataCombined = myDataCombinedTranformations) # Check the units of the observed time values obsData$`Vergin 1995.Iv`$xUnit #> [1] "h"  myDataCombinedTranformations$setDataTransformations(   forNames = obsData$`Vergin 1995.Iv`$name,   xOffsets = 24 )  plotIndividualTimeProfile(dataCombined = myDataCombinedTranformations) myDataCombinedTranformations$setDataTransformations(   forNames = obsData$`Vergin 1995.Iv`$name,   yScaleFactors = 1 / 250 )  plotIndividualTimeProfile(dataCombined = myDataCombinedTranformations)

title: Working with `DataCombined` class
text: data frame (also sometimes called table) data structure central R-based workflows, , thus, may wish extract data frame datasets present object. Internally, DataCombined extracts data frames observed simulated datasets combines . function returns tibble data frame. wish modify printed, can look available options . fact, let’s change options print data frame . ospsuite also provides helper functions modify data frame . multiple (observed /simulated) datasets present data frame, likely different units. convertUnits() function helps convert common unit. function modify DataCombined object return new data frame unified units.1.

title: Working with `DataCombined` class
text: Grouping simulated results observed data inside DataCombined also allows calculate error simulated results observations using calculateResiduals() function. function calculates distance observed data point within group simulated results. Simulation results interpolated simulated value available certain observed time point. Observed data beyond simulated time ignored, .e., extrapolation performed. two ways calculate distance (residuals) - linear logarithmic - specified scaling argument. linear scaling (scaling = tlf::Scaling$lin): Residuals calculated : Simulation value - Observed value. means residuals defined absolute differences. logarithmic scaling (scaling = tlf::Scaling$log): Residuals calculated : log(Simulation value) - log(Observed value) = log (Simulation Value / Observed Value). means ratio values considered independent magnitude value. small observed values, particular close 0 values, can lead problems, log(10E-N) = -N can becomes large. quickly calculate total error DataCombined, one can sum absolute values residuals:
code: # Linear residuals calculateResiduals(myDataCombined, scaling = tlf::Scaling$lin)$residualValues #>  [1]  9.49304275 -0.14538952  0.17965548  1.84599976  3.52552442  3.64160094 #>  [7]  3.15654735  2.38392729  1.48703530  0.50532597  0.08009793 -0.14892803 #> [13] -0.29395086  # Logarithmic residuals calculateResiduals(myDataCombined, scaling = tlf::Scaling$log)$residualValues #>  [1]  0.239719620 -0.007286928  0.012618336  0.155242835  0.384912455 #>  [6]  0.482210178  0.578799737  0.577914238  0.647582143  0.457679775 #> [11]  0.137321647 -0.418715711 -2.305882655 # Linear residuals totalError <- sum(abs(calculateResiduals(myDataCombined, scaling = tlf::Scaling$lin)$residualValues))  print(totalError) #> [1] 26.88703

what: Life cycle of a simulation run
title: Efficient calculation
text: general, user loads simulation, updates parameter values, calculates simulation retrieves results. steps inherent simulation: Loading simulation Optional: Setting parameter values Optional: Setting initial values Initializing simulation engine Solving ODE System (calculating outputs) Depending simulation interest, steps might take much longer others. example, simulation multiple administrations simulated many months load initialize quickly (1 4) calculating (5) critical step. hand, simulation dozens compounds also take time load initialize (1 4).

title: Efficient calculation
text: far easiest use cases. simulation loaded .pkml file outputs calculated. use case, step 4 5 automatically lumped together one single call (See Run Simulations details).

what: Running a single simulation multiple times and varying some parameters/initial values between each run
title: Efficient calculation
text: already use case optimal efficient way depends drastically simulation hand. Let’s assume want calculate outputs simulation different doses. simple implementation follow following idea, simulation loaded , dose value updated simulation calculated dose interest.  implementation fairly easy understand, potentially one big performance bottleneck. simulation run performed sequentially (.e. one time). means performance boost multiple cores machine. simulation takes seconds run, solution absolutely acceptable. However, assume simulation takes 1h run, code take 5h complete, runSimulations call executed sequentially. simulation run time (5) much greater loading (1) initialization time (4), better approach load simulation multiple times run simulation concurrently (.e. parallel).  Consider following implementation: implementation also fairly straight forward. load simulation multiple times file (note usage loadFromCache = FALSE ensure always get new instance simulation instance) set dose. , call runSimulations function list simulations. engine run simulations parallel, means overall execution time slightly 1h, run executed time.
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rSharp  # Load and run the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath) doseParameter <- getAllParametersMatching(toPathString("Applications", "**", "Dose"), sim)[[1]]  # run for dose 100mg doseParameter$value <- toBaseUnit(doseParameter, 100, "mg") result100 <- runSimulations(simulations = sim)  # run for dose 200mg doseParameter$value <- toBaseUnit(doseParameter, 200, "mg") result200 <- runSimulations(simulations = sim)  # ...  # run for dose 500mg doseParameter$value <- toBaseUnit(doseParameter, 500, "mg") result500 <- runSimulations(simulations = sim) library(ospsuite) # Load and run the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite")  loadSimulationWithDose <- function(doseInMg) {   sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath, loadFromCache = FALSE)   doseParameter <- getAllParametersMatching(toPathString("Applications", "**", "Dose"), sim)[[1]]   doseParameter$value <- toBaseUnit(doseParameter, doseInMg, "mg")   return(sim) }  # Creates 5 instances of a simulation (This is very fast for typical simulations) sim100 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 100) sim200 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 200) sim300 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 300) sim400 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 400) sim500 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 500)   # Runs the simulation in parallel results <- runSimulations(simulations = list(sim100, sim200, sim300, sim400, sim500))  # Results in now a list of SimulationResults

what: Optimized loading for running simulations with predefined set of variable parameters
title: Efficient calculation
text: advanced use case, typically implementing kind optimization sensitivity algorithms. ospsuite package introduces concept simulation batch. simulation batch, variable parameters (initial values) simulation vary run specified explicitly creation simulation batch. allows simulation engine speed system significantly equations can rewritten simplified. simulation batch also keeps simplified simulation memory. means running simulation new set values much faster, initialization phase (4) done required every run.  Consider following implementation. first create two simulation batches model define parameter values can changed runs. Note , opposed Simulation object, access parameter/species values can change outputs simulation time. next step, define multiple runs simulation batch adding different parameter (/species start) values set. set values correspond one run. benefit approach initialization steps (1 4) performed . , execution time (step 5) impact total performance. far, created 2 simulation batches, one 3 parameter sets one 4. means 3 runs enqueued simBatch1 4 enqueued simBatch2. run gets unique id can later used correctly assign simulation results simulated set parameters. enqueued run values cleared calling runSimulationBatches(), executing run result empty results list. can now set values batches run . Notes: - always set number values time - Previous runValues automatically cleared runSimulationBatches() called. Usage SimulationBatch recommended advanced scenarios simulations expected run hundreds times second can spared impact performance significantly.
code: library(ospsuite) simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite")  # We load the simulation for which the batches will be created sim1 <- loadSimulation(simFilePath, loadFromCache = FALSE)  # define the list of parameter that will be varied between the runs. # For the first batch, we will vary 2 parameters: Lipophilicity and Permeability parameterPaths <- c("Aciclovir|Lipophilicity", "Aciclovir|Permeability")  # define a first simulation batch simBatch1 <- createSimulationBatch(simulation = sim1, parametersOrPaths = parameterPaths)  # for the second batch, we will vary Molecular Weight simBatch2 <- createSimulationBatch(   simulation = sim1,   parametersOrPaths = c("Aciclovir|Molecular weight") )  simulationBatches <- list(simBatch1, simBatch2) # now setting some parameter run values (the size of the array should match # the number of parameters to vary for each batch simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(1, 2)) #> [1] "076952c0-6f79-4c8b-ac56-45e9d086afed" simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(3, 4)) #> [1] "9bfe2260-7ecd-4dab-b294-e50d5eb4c530" simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(5, 6)) #> [1] "2cebdcac-582b-4671-8f81-e34f3d048454"  # We only have one parameter to vary for simBatch2, therefore only one value to set simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 150) #> [1] "b80c6cab-f78d-44e1-9bba-6fcb30f9d94d" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 200) #> [1] "7555786f-b2b3-4c90-8575-7a51428fe0a5" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 300) #> [1] "8f493155-563e-41f0-a57b-fbea35c5765d" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 400) #> [1] "a2cf9e75-7675-4009-896b-666e0f2eae67" # Now we run the simulation batches. # By doing so, 7 runs (3 for simBatch1 and 4 for simBatch2) will be executed in parallel. # Please see documentation of runSimulationBatches for more details. # The resulting output is a named list, where the names are the ids of the enqueued runs. results <- runSimulationBatches(simulationBatches) print(names(unlist(results))) #> [1] "2a133355-fcc8-4d8b-950c-2e2a2631994e.076952c0-6f79-4c8b-ac56-45e9d086afed" #> [2] "2a133355-fcc8-4d8b-950c-2e2a2631994e.9bfe2260-7ecd-4dab-b294-e50d5eb4c530" #> [3] "2a133355-fcc8-4d8b-950c-2e2a2631994e.2cebdcac-582b-4671-8f81-e34f3d048454" #> [4] "4b13f345-bc3d-484c-ba07-0db1cfd5da1d.b80c6cab-f78d-44e1-9bba-6fcb30f9d94d" #> [5] "4b13f345-bc3d-484c-ba07-0db1cfd5da1d.7555786f-b2b3-4c90-8575-7a51428fe0a5" #> [6] "4b13f345-bc3d-484c-ba07-0db1cfd5da1d.8f493155-563e-41f0-a57b-fbea35c5765d" #> [7] "4b13f345-bc3d-484c-ba07-0db1cfd5da1d.a2cf9e75-7675-4009-896b-666e0f2eae67" simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(10, 20)) #> [1] "257a3f92-f29c-44fc-8fcd-1cdcf44ee9e7" simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(30, 40)) #> [1] "32e46e3c-c360-4c32-ac6b-43ad26fcdc63" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 500) #> [1] "08e647f1-28f7-4624-af04-ffca90622063" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 200) #> [1] "322996f7-c0a0-410c-9da8-1c4a89148f4b"  # this run will be much faster as the simulation won't be initialized again. # Only the new value will be set as specified when adding new run values with addRunValues results2 <- runSimulationBatches(simulationBatches)  # Once the simulation batches instances are not needed anymore, they can be removed # from the environment and the allocated memory cleared. # This will be done automatically when the R session is terminated. rm(simBatch1) rm(simBatch2)

previous_headings: Optimized loading for running simulations with predefined set of variable parameters
what: Varying state variable parameters with SimulationBatch
title: Efficient calculation
text: State variable parameters, .e., defined right hand side (RHS), treated molecules internally. Trying create run simulation batch state variable parameter set variable parameter result error: Instead, state variable parameter treated species set variable molecule start value.
code: stateVariableParam <- getParameter(path = "Organism|Lumen|Stomach|Liquid", container = sim1) print(stateVariableParam) #> <Parameter> #>   • Quantity Type: Parameter #>   • Path: Organism|Lumen|Stomach|Liquid #>   • Value: 0.05 [l] #>  #> ── Formula ── #>  #>   • isExplicit: TRUE #>   • formula: V*SteadyStateFillLevel #>   • Value overrides formula: FALSE #>  #> ── State variable ── #>  #>   • isStateVariable: TRUE #>  #> ── RHSFormula #>   • isExplicit: TRUE #>   • formula: OralApplicationsEnabled ? -LT_sto + Inflow*FillLevelFlag : 0  # Create simulation batch with state variable parameter set as a variable parameter simBatch <- createSimulationBatch(simulation = sim1, parametersOrPaths = stateVariableParam)  # Add run values resId <- simBatch$addRunValues(parameterValues = 0.5) # Try to run batch results <- runSimulationBatches(simBatch) #> Error in do.call(".External", c(list("r_call_method", self$pointer, methodName), : Type:    OSPSuite.Core.Domain.InvalidArgumentException #> Message: Entities 'Organism|Lumen|Stomach|Liquid' do not exist in the simulation #> Method:  Void validate(System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList`1[System.String], System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList`1[System.String]) #> Stack trace: #>    at OSPSuite.R.Domain.SimulationBatch.validate(IReadOnlyList`1 entitiesToVary, IReadOnlyList`1 entitiesThatWillBeVaried) #>    at OSPSuite.R.Domain.SimulationBatch.validate(SimulationBatchOptions simulationBatchOptions) #>    at OSPSuite.R.Domain.SimulationBatch.Initialize(IModelCoreSimulation simulation, SimulationBatchOptions simulationBatchOptions, SimulationRunOptions simulationRunOptions) #>    at OSPSuite.R.Domain.SimulationBatchFactory.Create(IModelCoreSimulation modelCoreSimulation, SimulationBatchOptions simulationBatchOptions, SimulationRunOptions simulationRunOptions) #>    at OSPSuite.R.Domain.ConcurrentRunSimulationBatch.AddNewBatch(SimulationRunOptions simulationRunOptions) #>    at OSPSuite.R.Servi stateVariableParam <- getParameter(path = "Organism|Lumen|Stomach|Liquid", container = sim1) # Create simulation batch with state variable parameter set as a variable molecule simBatch <- createSimulationBatch(simulation = sim1, moleculesOrPaths = stateVariableParam) # Add run values resId <- simBatch$addRunValues(initialValues = 0.5) # Try to run batch results <- runSimulationBatches(simBatch)

title: Loading a simulation and accessing entities
text: general, every workflow starts loading simulation calling loadSimulation() function. function receives full path *.pkml file format exported PK-Sim MoBi, returns corresponding simulation object.
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rSharp  simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite")  sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)

what: Accessing entities of the model and their properties - the path concept
title: Loading a simulation and accessing entities
text: simulation loaded, possible retrieve various entities model. important entities containers, molecules, parameters. methods getContainer, getMolecule, getParameter search respective entity given path located container. path string elements path (.e., containers hierarchy simulation) separated |. container instance Container-class within model structure path relative . cases, container Simulation object created calling loadSimulation(pkmlSimulationFile). functions getAllContainersMatching(), getAllMoleculesMatching(), getAllParametersMatching() return list objects representing entities whose paths match generic paths provided list paths located container. Generic paths constructed using wildcard symbols * (exactly one occurrence element) ** (zero occurrences element). Note path "Organism|Kidney|*|Intracellular|Volume" return parameters standard models, sub-containers Kidney Intracellular. contrast, "Organism|Kidney|**|Intracellular|Volume" valid path. functions getAllContainersMatching(), getAllMoleculesMatching(), getAllParametersMatching() can also used retrieve entities multiple paths: entities possess various properties can accessed objects. important properties container : important properties molecule : important properties parameter :
code: # Get the molecule Aciclovir located in kidney intracellular space moleculeInKid <- getMolecule("Organism|Kidney|Intracellular|Aciclovir", sim) print(moleculeInKid) #> <Molecule> #>   • Path: Organism|Kidney|Intracellular|Aciclovir #>   • Scale Divisor: 1 #>   • Initial Value: 0.00e+00 [µmol]  # Get the container "Liver" livContainer <- getContainer("Organism|Liver", sim) print(livContainer) #> <Container> #>   • Container type: Organ #>   • Path: Organism|Liver  # Get the parameter volume of the liver interstitial space # Note that the path used is relative to the liver container livParam <- getParameter("Interstitial|Volume", livContainer) print(livParam) #> <Parameter> #>   • Quantity Type: Parameter #>   • Path: Organism|Liver|Interstitial|Volume #>   • Value: 0.35 [l] #>  #> ── Formula ── #>  #>   • isExplicit: TRUE #>   • formula: f_int*V #>   • Value overrides formula: FALSE # Get the parameter `Volume` of the intracellular space of all organs, # with exactly one path element before `Intracellular` volumeParams <- getAllParametersMatching("Organism|*|Intracellular|Volume", sim) length(volumeParams) #> [1] 15 # The PBPK model has 15 organs with an "Intracellular" sub-compartment  # Get the parameter `Volume` of the intracellular space of all organs, # no matter how many sub-containers the organ has volumeParams <- getAllParametersMatching("Organism|**|Intracellular|Volume", sim) length(volumeParams) #> [1] 28 # The list also includes parameters of organs like "Liver|Periportal", # or the mucosal compartments of the intestine. # Get the molecule Aciclovir located in `Liver|Periportal|Intracellular` and `VenousBlood|Plasma` molecules <- getAllMoleculesMatching(c(   "Organism|VenousBlood|Plasma|Aciclovir",   "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir" ), sim) print(molecules) #> [[1]] #> <Molecule> #>   • Path: Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir #>   • Scale Divisor: 1 #>   • Initial Value: 0.00e+00 [µmol] #>  #> [[2]] #> <Molecule> #>   • Path: Organism|VenousBlood|Plasma|Aciclovir #>   • Scale Divisor: 1 #>   • Initial Value: 0.00e+00 [µmol] # Path of the container livContainer$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver"  # Parent container livContainer$parentContainer #> <Container> #>   • Container type: Organism #>   • Path: Organism # Initial value of the molecule moleculeInKid$value #> [1] 0  # Dimension of the molecule. See section "Unit conversion" for more information. moleculeInKid$dimension #> [1] "Amount"  # Is the initial value defined by a formula? moleculeInKid$isFormula #> [1] FALSE  # Type of the formula. CONSTANT if the value is defined by a constant. moleculeInKid$formula #> <Formula> #>   • isConstant: TRUE # Initial value of the parameter livParam$value #> [1] 0.3533005  # Dimension of the parameter. See section "Unit conversion" for more information. livParam$dimension #> [1] "Volume"  # Base unit of the parameter. See section "Unit conversion" for more information. livParam$unit #> [1] "l"  # Is the initial value defined by a formula? livParam$isFormula #> [1] TRUE  # Type of the formula. CONSTANT if the value is defined by a constant. livParam$formula #> <Formula> #>   • isExplicit: TRUE #>   • formula: f_int*V

title: Loading a simulation and accessing entities
text: convenient way traverse simulation structure given method getSimulationTree. method generates tree-like list paths within simulation. element tree contains sub-containers element. final elements strings representing path entity.
code: # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Create simulation tree simTree <- getSimulationTree(sim)  # Calling simTree would list all entities within the simulation # (given how long this tree can be, we will skip it here, but you can try # running the following command in your console) # simTree  # Accessing the parameter "Organism|Weight" simTree$Organism$Weight #> $path #> [1] "Organism|Weight"  # Getting all entities located under "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular" entitiesList <- simTree$Organism$Liver$Periportal$Intracellular entitiesList #> $`Volume of protein container` #> $`Volume of protein container`$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Volume of protein container" #>  #>  #> $Volume #> $Volume$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Volume" #>  #>  #> $pH #> $pH$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|pH" #>  #>  #> $Aciclovir #> $Aciclovir$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir" #>  #> $Aciclovir$Concentration #> $Aciclovir$Concentration$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir|Concentration" #>  #>  #> $Aciclovir$`Partition coefficient (water/container)` #> $Aciclovir$`Partition coefficient (water/container)`$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir|Partition coefficient (water/container)" #>  #>  #> $Aciclovir$`Concentration in container` #> $Aciclovir$`Concentration in container`$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir|Concentration in container"

title: Observed data
text: DataSet object stores numerical data pairs - typically time x values measurement y values - optionally measurement error . values dimension unit (see Dimensions Units information). Furthermore, DataSet must name. creating DataSet scratch (e.g. user wants manually input observed data), name must provided: creation, DataSet hold data. default dimension unit x values Time h, respectively. default dimension unit y values Concentration (mass) mg/l, respectively. dimension error values always corresponds dimension y values, though units may differ. Setting numerical values (overwriting current values) performed $setValues() method: user can change dimensions units values. changing dimension, unit automatically set base unit dimension. Changing dimension unit transform values. Two types error values supported - arithmetic error (default) geometric error, latter given fraction. user can change error type: DataSet can store kind text meta data name-values pairs can added addMetaData() method: DataSet multiple DataSets can converted data.frame (tibble) processed downstream analysis visualization workflows:
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rSharp  # Create an empty data set dataSet <- DataSet$new("My data set") dataSet$setValues(   xValues = c(1, 2, 3, 4),   yValues = c(0, 0.1, 0.6, 10),   yErrorValues = c(0.001, 0.001, 0.1, 1) )  print(dataSet) #> <DataSet> #>   • Name: My data set #>   • X dimension: Time #>   • X unit: h #>   • Y dimension: Concentration (mass) #>   • Y unit: mg/l #>   • Error type: ArithmeticStdDev #>   • Error unit: mg/l #>   • Molecular weight: NULL #>   • LLOQ: NULL #> Meta data: # Print x, y, and error values dataSet$xValues #> [1] 1 2 3 4 dataSet$yValues #> [1]  0.0  0.1  0.6 10.0 dataSet$yErrorValues #> [1] 0.001 0.001 0.100 1.000  # Change the unit of x-values dataSet$xUnit <- ospUnits$Time$min # Print the x values - they did not change dataSet$xValues #> [1] 1 2 3 4  # Change dimension of y-values dataSet$yDimension <- ospDimensions$Amount  print(dataSet) #> <DataSet> #>   • Name: My data set #>   • X dimension: Time #>   • X unit: min #>   • Y dimension: Amount #>   • Y unit: µmol #>   • Error type: ArithmeticStdDev #>   • Error unit: µmol #>   • Molecular weight: NULL #>   • LLOQ: NULL #> Meta data:  # Change the units of y values and error values - they are now different! dataSet$yUnit <- ospUnits$Amount$mol dataSet$yErrorUnit <- ospUnits$Amount$pmol  print(dataSet) #> <DataSet> #>   • Name: My data set #>   • X dimension: Time #>   • X unit: min #>   • Y dimension: Amount #>   • Y unit: mol #>   • Error type: ArithmeticStdDev #>   • Error unit: pmol #>   • Molecular weight: NULL #>   • LLOQ: NULL #> Meta data: # Default error type is "ArithmeticStdDev" dataSet$yErrorType #> [1] "ArithmeticStdDev"  # Change error type to geometric dataSet$yErrorType <- DataErrorType$GeometricStdDev # Error unit is "Unitless" for dimension "Fraction". dataSet$yErrorUnit #> [1] ""  # Changing error type to arithmetic will set the dimension and unit of the error # to the same dimension and unit as the y values dataSet$yErrorType <- DataErrorType$ArithmeticStdDev  print(dataSet) #> <DataSet> #>   • Name: My data set #>   • X dimension: Time #>   • X unit: min #>   • Y dimension: Amount #>   • Y unit: mol #>   • Error type: ArithmeticStdDev #>   • Error unit: mol #>   • Molecular weight: NULL #>   • LLOQ: NULL #> Meta data: # Add new meta data entries dataSet$addMetaData(   name = "Molecule",   value = "Aciclovir" ) dataSet$addMetaData(   name = "Organ",   value = "Muscle" )  # Print meta data of the DataSet print(dataSet$metaData) #> $Molecule #> [1] "Aciclovir" #>  #> $Organ #> [1] "Muscle" # Create a second data set dataSet2 <- DataSet$new(name = "Second data set") dataSet2$setValues(   xValues = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5),   yValues = c(1, 0, 5, 8, 0.1) )  # Convert data sets to a tibble myTibble <- dataSetToTibble(dataSets = c(dataSet, dataSet2))  print(myTibble) #> # A tibble: 9 × 14 #>   name            xValues yValues yErrorValues xDimension xUnit yDimension yUnit #>   <chr>             <dbl>   <dbl>        <dbl> <chr>      <chr> <chr>      <chr> #> 1 My data set           1   0          0.00100 Time       min   Amount     mol   #> 2 My data set           2   0.1        0.00100 Time       min   Amount     mol   #> 3 My data set           3   0.6        0.1     Time       min   Amount     mol   #> 4 My data set           4  10          1       Time       min   Amount     mol   #> 5 Second data set       1   1.00      NA       Time       h     Concentra… mg/l  #> 6 Second data set       2   0         NA       Time       h     Concentra… mg/l  #> 7 Second data set       3   5.00      NA       Time       h     Concentra… mg/l  #> 8 Second data set       4   8.00      NA       Time       h     Concentra… mg/l  #> 9 Second data set       5   0.100     NA       Time       h     Concentra… mg/l  #> # ℹ 6 more variables: yErrorType <chr>, yErrorUnit <chr>, molWeight <dbl>, #> #   lloq <dbl>, Molecule <chr>, Organ <chr>

title: Observed data
text: Creating DataSet objects scratch rather advanced use case. Typically, observed data loaded either *.pkml files exported PK-Sim MoBi, imported Excel files. function loadDataSetFromPKML() loads data *.pkml file. Complementary function function saveDataSetToPKML() allows export DataSet *.pkml can loaded e.g. MoBi. Another (probably important) way create DataSet objects importing data excel files. function loadDataSetsFromExcel() utilizes data import functionality implemented PK-Sim MoBi returns set DataSet objects. description supported file formats configurations, please refer OSPS documentation. Loading observed data Excel sheet requires ImporterConfiguration. configuration describes mapping excel sheet columns numerical data (e.g.  column contains x values) meta data (e.g., description applied dose). One way obtain configuration create PK-Sim MoBi, save (*.xml) file, load R loadDataImporterConfiguration() function: data importer configuration can also created scratch manually populated user. Alternatively, user can let software “guess” configuration given excel sheet: important manually check created configuration, automated configuration recognition cover possible cases. specific sheets excel file imported, can specified ImporterConfiguration. following example loads sheets TestSheet_1 TestSheet_1_withMW: Currently, DataImporterConfiguration created scratch specific data sheet support features importer configuration, specifying column containing molecular weight measured molecule LLOQ values. therefore recommended use importer configurations created PK-Si MoBi.
code: # Load a data set from PKML filePath <- system.file("extdata", "ObsDataAciclovir_1.pkml", package = "ospsuite")  dataSet <- loadDataSetFromPKML(filePath = filePath)  print(dataSet) #> <DataSet> #>   • Name: Vergin 1995.Iv #>   • X dimension: Time #>   • X unit: h #>   • Y dimension: Concentration (mass) #>   • Y unit: mg/l #>   • Error type: ArithmeticStdDev #>   • Error unit: mg/l #>   • Molecular weight: 225.21 #>   • LLOQ: NULL #> Meta data: #>   • Source: X:\Orga\BTS-TD\ET\TP CSB\Projects\Internal #>   Projects\MagenDarm\TestSubstanzen\Acyclovir\Rohdaten_Acyclovir.xls.Vergin #>   1995 250 mg iv #>   • File: Rohdaten_Acyclovir #>   • Sheet: Vergin 1995 250 mg iv #>   • Molecule: Aciclovir #>   • Species: Human #>   • Organ: Peripheral Venous Blood #>   • Compartment: Plasma #>   • Study Id: Vergin 1995 #>   • Gender: Undefined #>   • Dose: 250 mg #>   • Route: IV #>   • Patient Id: Iv # Load a configuration from xml file filePath <- system.file("extdata", "dataImporterConfiguration.xml", package = "ospsuite") importerConfiguration <- loadDataImporterConfiguration(configurationFilePath = filePath)  print(importerConfiguration) #> <DataImporterConfiguration> #>   • Time column: Time [h] #>   • Time unit: h #>   • Time unit from column: FALSE #>   • Measurement column: Concentration (mass)[ng/ml] #>   • Measurement unit: ng/ml #>   • Measurement unit from column: FALSE #>   • Error column: Error [ng/ml] #>   • Error type: ArithmeticStdDev #>   • Error unit: ng/ml #>   • Grouping columns: Study Id, Organ, Compartment, Species, Gender, Molecule, #>   Route, MW, Patient Id, Dose [unit] #>   • Sheets: <empty vector> #>   • Naming pattern: {Source}.{Sheet}.{Study #>   Id}.{Organ}.{Compartment}.{Species}.{Gender}.{Molecule}.{Route}.{Molecular #>   Weight}.{Subject Id}.{Dose} # Excel file excelFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "CompiledDataSet.xlsx", package = "ospsuite") sheetName <- "TestSheet_1"  # Create importer configuration for the excel sheet importerConfiguration_guessed <- createImporterConfigurationForFile(   filePath = excelFilePath,   sheet = sheetName )  print(importerConfiguration) #> <DataImporterConfiguration> #>   • Time column: Time [h] #>   • Time unit: h #>   • Time unit from column: FALSE #>   • Measurement column: Concentration (mass)[ng/ml] #>   • Measurement unit: ng/ml #>   • Measurement unit from column: FALSE #>   • Error column: Error [ng/ml] #>   • Error type: ArithmeticStdDev #>   • Error unit: ng/ml #>   • Grouping columns: Study Id, Organ, Compartment, Species, Gender, Molecule, #>   Route, MW, Patient Id, Dose [unit] #>   • Sheets: <empty vector> #>   • Naming pattern: {Source}.{Sheet}.{Study #>   Id}.{Organ}.{Compartment}.{Species}.{Gender}.{Molecule}.{Route}.{Molecular #>   Weight}.{Subject Id}.{Dose} # Excel file excelFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "CompiledDataSet.xlsx", package = "ospsuite") sheetName <- "TestSheet_1"  # Create importer configuration for the excel sheet importerConfiguration_guessed <- createImporterConfigurationForFile(   filePath = excelFilePath,   sheet = sheetName ) # Add sheet names to the configuration importerConfiguration_guessed$sheets <- c("TestSheet_1", "TestSheet_1_withMW")  # Load data dataSets <- loadDataSetsFromExcel(   xlsFilePath = excelFilePath,   importerConfigurationOrPath = importerConfiguration_guessed )

title: Introduction to ospsuite
text: order load simulation R, must present *.pkml file format. Every simulation PK-Sim MoBi can exported *.pkml file. Unless otherwise stated, examples shown vignettes based Aciclovir example model. model can found PK-Sim examples folder OSPS installation. general workflow ospsuite package can summarized following steps: Loading simulation .pkml file. Accessing entities simulation, molecules, parameters, containers, reading information . Changing simulation settings, parameter values, molecules start values. Retrieving results processing . workflow steps described following vignettes: Loading simulation accessing entities Changing parameter molecule start values Running simulation Efficient calculations Creating individuals Population simulations PK Analysis Sensitivity analysis Table parameters Dimensions Units Working data sets import excel Working DataCombined class Visualizations DataCombined aspects ospsuite package may appear uncommon users familiar object-oriented approach. recommended read following section better understand semantics get flexibility efficiency package.

title: Introduction to ospsuite
text: ospsuite R-package utilizes concept object oriented (OO) programming based R6 system. philosophy package offer functional programming workflow common R users, important understand basic concepts OO programming. functions implemented ospsuite return instance (object) class. objects can used inputs functions. Additionally, object offers set properties (can objects) functions, accessible $ sign: Important information object can printed calling print(object). important classes : Simulation Representation simulation loaded *.pkml file. SimulationRunOptions object defining options simulation run. options : numberOfCores maximal number (logical) cores can used (population) simulation; checkForNegativeValues boolean defining error thrown variables become negative "negativeValuesAllowed"-flag set FALSE (can used ignore numerical noise); showProgress Boolean “progress bar” shown console representing progress simulation. SolverSettings Object defining settings solver. Stored SimulationSettings Simulation (accessibly field $settings). OutputSchema Definition output intervals simulation. OutputSchema defines total simulation time time points results generated. Can accessed property Simulation-object. OutputSelections List quantities (parameters molecules) outputs generated. Can accessed property Simulation-object. SimulationResults Results simulation, either individual population. Holds simulated values quantities defined OutputSelections. See Running simulation information. Entity Every accessible distinct part model. prominent entities Molecule, Parameter, Container. Every Entity properties $path representing path within model structure $parentContainer container entity located . Container Container element model structure contains entities (e.g., spatial containers, molecules, parameters). prominent containers organs compartments. loaded Simulation also container. Quantity Entity simulation value - namely Molecule Parameter. Every Quantity $value $dimension. important fields $unit, base unit dimension. See Dimensions Units information. Molecule molecule located Container. $value-property refers initial value simulation. Inherits Quantity. Parameter parameter. $value-property refers initial value simulation. Inherits Quantity. Formula value Quantity described $formula-property. different types formulae, see Changing parameter molecule start values information. IndividualCharacteristics object used creating individual parameter sets createIndividual-method. See Creating individuals information. Population object describing virtual population. Can either loaded *.csv-file created PK-Sim created createPopulation-method. See Population simulations information. PopulationCharacteristics object used creating population parameter sets createPopulation-method. See Population simulations information. SimulationPKAnalyses PK analyses simulations result. QuantityPKParameter certain PK parameter output quantity. fields $name name PK parameter (e.g. “C_max”), $quantityPath path output parameter calculated , $values value (list values population simulation). SensitivityAnalysis class defining analysis input parameters impact output curves simulation. See Sensitivity analysis information. SensitivityAnalysisResults Results running SensitivityAnalysis PKParameterSensitivity sensitivity (field $value) PK-Parameter ($pkParameterName) output $outputPath calculated varied parameter $parameterName. See Sensitivity analysis information.
code: object1           <- ClassName$new() aProperty         <- object1$property1 resultOfAFunction <- object1$multiply(1,2)

title: Calculating PK parameters of simulation outputs
text: ospsuite package gives access standard PK Parameters calculated PK-Sim AUC, Cmax etc. complete list PK Parameters supported box, please refer online documentation. PK parameters can calculated outputs simulation. First, simulation results must calculated, SimulationResults object passed method calculatePKAnalyses. list calculated PK parameters description, please refer OSPS documentation. function calculatePKAnalyses returns object class SimulationPKAnalyses, allows retrieve either certain PK parameter output path, calculated PK parameters output path. methods $allPKParametersFor() $pKParameterFor() return object (list objects) class QuantityPKParameter, fields $name name pk-parameter (e.g. “C_max”), $quantityPath path output parameter calculated , $values value (list values population simulation). case population simulation, $values return list values calculated individual.
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rSharp  # Load the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Run the simulation simulationResults <- runSimulations(simulations = sim)[[1]]  # Calculate PK-analyses pkAnalysis <- calculatePKAnalyses(results = simulationResults)  # Get the path of the simulated output outputPath <- simulationResults$allQuantityPaths[[1]] print(outputPath) #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)"  # Get all calculated PK parameters for the output path allPkParams <- pkAnalysis$allPKParametersFor(outputPath) print(allPkParams) #> [[1]] #> <QuantityPKParameter> #>   • Name: C_max #>   • QuantityPath: Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral #>   Venous Blood) #>   • Dimension: Concentration (molar) #>   • Unit: µmol/l #>  #> [[2]] #> <QuantityPKParameter> #>   • Name: C_max_norm • Name: t_max #>   • QuantityPath: Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral #>   Venous Blood) #>   • Dimension: Time #>   • Unit: min #>  #> [[4]] #> <QuantityPKParameter> #>   • Name: C_tEnd #>   • QuantityPath: Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral #>   Venous Blood) #>   • Dimension: Concentration (molar) #>   • Unit: µmol/l #>  #> [[5]] #> Unit: kg*min/l #>  #> [[7]] #> <QuantityPKParameter> #>   • Name: AUC_inf #>   • QuantityPath: Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral #>   Venous Blood) #>   • Dimension: AUC (molar) #>   • Unit: µmol*min/l #>  #> [[8]] #> <QuantityPKParameter> #>   • Name: AUC_inf_norm #>   • QuantityPath: Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral #>   Venous Blood) #>   • Dimension: AUC (mass) #>   • Unit: kg*min/l #>  #> [[9]] #> <QuantityPKParameter> #>   • Name: MRT #>   • QuantityPath: Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral #>   Venous Blood) #>   • Dimension: Time #>   • Unit: min #>  #> [[10]] #> <QuantityPKParameter> #>   • Name: Thalf #>   • QuantityPath: Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral #>   Venous Blood) #>
